the integrated areas provides a hint of the lithiumoccupancy of
each site. Information on lithium diﬀusion, on the other hand,
is obtained either fromlineshape analysis of static NMR spectra
as a function of temperature, or it is obtained fromrelaxometry
The situation in Li-conducting garnets is, however, compli-
cated by several factors. First, the range of Li chemical shis
) in these materials is very narrow, which makes it diﬃcult
to perform an unambiguous assignment to specic lithium
sites. This is especially critical when only
ded because dipolar broadening, even in MAS spectroscopy,
obscures the eventual separation of bands with diﬀerent
MAS-NMR provides a considerably higher resolution, but has
the disadvantage of a lower signal to noise sensitivity because
this isotope is only 7% abundant in natural lithium. There is
another diﬃculty, namely, the presence of lithium-containing
impurities. This aspect is oen underestimated, an omission
that is particularly relevant in Li garnets due to the tendency
of these compounds to form second phases, such as lithium
hydroxides or lithium carbonate as a result of the facile
exchange of lithium by protons from ambient air.
explanation for this contribution being frequently disregarded
is that most of such phases are light-weight compared with the
weight of garnet itself, which makes them not easily detectable
by the X-ray diﬀraction methods routinely used to characterize
the phase purity of the samples.

tion they suggest that the signal at lower
around 1.2–1.3 ppm in cubic, Al-stabilized c-LLZO.
chemical shi values and the narrow linewidths led these
authors to attribute this band to the tetrahedral sites, in which
lithium atoms would spend most of their time. Regarding the

, and were interpreted as arising from “non-
mobile” and “mobile” lithiumions of the garnet lattice.

, with a Li distribution similar to LLZO, Galven

of the stoichiometric compound, and they found two signals, at

parameters have also been determined by a number of authors,
Li spectra as a function of
In this work we present an NMR study of LLZO garnets with
the aim of identifying the bands arising from the diﬀerent
lithiumsites occupied in the lattice. To enhance both resolution
and sensitivity we present (for the rst time to our knowledge)
Li-MAS-NMR spectra recorded in samples enriched with
isotope. Taking advantage of the known sensitivity of this
material to moisture and facile proton-for-lithiumexchange, we
altered the relative population of tetrahedral and octahedral
sites by submitting the samples to diﬀerent post-treatments to
obtain samples with varying lithium contents. The character-
istics of proton bonding have also been analyzed using
able temperature measurements have indicated the presence of
synthesized by a solid state reaction at temperatures between
added to the stoichiometric ratio to compensate lithium loss
In order to vary the lithium content in the garnet, Li
exchange was performed by submitting a fresh tetragonal
sample to prolonged annealing in air both at 350
In addition to the garnet phase, lithium hydroxide and lithium
carbonate were detected as secondary phases coming from the
proton for lithium exchange process. Both phases are water
soluble, thus with the aim of clarifying the NMR spectra, the
aged samples were dipped in water for 2 min under stirring, and
then ltered and dried. Using XRD and Raman spectroscopy we
have veried that no changes take place in the garnet aer the
washing treatment, indicating that only the secondary phases
The chemical composition of the synthesized materials was
determined by ICP-OES (inductively coupled plasma optical
emission spectrometry). Within the experimental error, the La
and Zr content were close to the stoichiometric composition.
X-ray diﬀraction (XRD) experiments were performed on
a Rigaku D/max 2500 diﬀractometer equipped with Cu K
A) radiation and working at 40 kV and 80 mA. Data
were collected in a step mode with
time of 1 s per step. XRPD patterns were analyzed by the Riet-
Raman dispersion measurements were performed using a
DILOR XY spectrometer with a CCD detector and at a spectral
. The 514.53 nm line of an Ar
was used as the excitation source, and the power at the sample
25 mW. The scattered light was collected through
an X50 microscope objective lens. A LinkamTS1500V stage was
